itemDescription: Church of England clergyman and author

wikipedia_page.main: William Adams (1814–1848), Church of England clergyman and author of Christian allegories popular in Britain in the 19th century.

response: William Adams may refer to:
*William Adams (Royal Navy officer, died 1748), British naval officer
*William Adams (Royal Navy officer, born 1716) (1716–1763), British naval officer
*William Adams (pilot) (1564–1620), English sailor and samurai in Japan
*Willy Northpole (William Adams, born 1980), rapper signed to Ludacris' DTP Records
*William Adams (British Columbia politician) (1851–1936), rancher and politician in British Columbia, Canada
*William Adams (1752–1811), MP for Totnes

*William Adams (locomotive engineer) (1823–1904), British locomotive engineer

*William Adams (oculist) (1783–1827), English ophthalmic surgeon
*William Adams (cricketer) (1885–1957), English cricketer
*William Adams (footballer), footballer who played for Walsall and West Bromwich Albion
*William Adams (wrestler), British wrestler

*William Adams (Dedham) (1650–1685), minister of the First Church and Parish in Dedham

The 1847 religious story The Old Man's Home by William Adams features a description of the East End landslip in the 1840s after its vegetation was re-established.Adams, William, The Old Man's Home, Rivingtons, 1870, Internet Archive oldmanshome00adamgoog

The family experienced money difficulties through the failure of two local banks, and the father died in 1842 deep in debt. Elizabeth and the other children undertook to pay off the creditors, and set aside a certain sum each year from her literary earnings, until all was repaid. Until 1844 the family lived at Pidford Manor or Ventnor, but in that year Mrs Sewell and her daughters settled at Sea View, Bonchurch. Elizabeth bought the house, enlarged it in 1854, and later changed its name to Ashcliff. At Bonchurch, she met William Adams, another High Church author of religious works.

on the Isle of Wight (retrieved 9 July 2013) and houses built for the industrialist William Spindler in the 1880s during his attempt, cut short by his death, to develop St Lawrence as a town.The Isle of Wight, David Wharton Lloyd, Nikolaus Pevsner, Yale University Press, 2006, , Bonchurch was a particular focus of development, a number of elite Victorians renting or owning homes there (e.g. William Adams, Thomas Carlyle, Charles Dickens, Henry Beaumont Leeson, Lord Macaulay, Elizabeth Missing Sewell, and Henry De Vere Stacpoole).
*William Adams (18141848), an Anglican cleric who wrote Christian allegories.
